metadata.description: Core PowerView commands for Active Directory enumeration
metadata.author: OSCP Reference

commands.name: Import PowerView Module
commands.description: Load PowerView module into PowerShell session to enable Active Directory enumeration cmdlets. PowerView is a PowerShell tool for gaining network situational awareness on Windows domains. This must be run before any PowerView cmdlets can be used.

variables.name: <PATH>
variables.description: Directory path where PowerView.ps1 is located

output_analysis: No output on success (silent load)
Error messages indicate missing file or execution policy restrictions
Use 'Get-Command -Module PowerView' to verify loaded cmdlets
common_uses: Initial setup for AD enumeration session
Loading PowerView after gaining PowerShell access on domain-joined Windows host
First step in domain reconnaissance from compromised system
failure_indicators: Cannot be loaded because running scripts is disabled

troubleshooting.file not found: Verify PowerView.ps1 path and use full absolute path
troubleshooting.access denied: Ensure current user has read permissions on file

commands.notes: PowerView.ps1 may trigger AV detection. Consider using obfuscated versions or AMSI bypass techniques. For OSCP, usually safe on target machines. Alternative: Use native AD cmdlets if PowerView unavailable.

commands.name: Get Domain Information
commands.description: Retrieve detailed information about the current domain or specified domain. Returns domain name, domain controllers, forest name, and other critical AD infrastructure details. Essential for understanding the target AD environment structure.
output_analysis: Forest: Parent forest name
DomainControllers: List of DC hostnames
Name: NetBIOS domain name
DomainSID: Domain Security Identifier (critical for Golden Ticket attacks)
common_uses: First enumeration step after importing PowerView
Identify domain controllers for targeted enumeration
Obtain domain SID for advanced attacks
Map out multi-domain forest structure
success_indicators: Returns domain object with multiple properties

troubleshooting.no output: Verify host is domain-joined: systeminfo | findstr /B /C:"Domain"
troubleshooting.access denied: Current user may lack domain query permissions

commands.notes: The DomainSID is particularly valuable - save it for potential Golden/Silver Ticket attacks. For OSCP, focus on identifying Domain Controllers and understanding domain structure. Manual alternative: 'nltest /dclist:<domain>'

commands.name: Enumerate Domain Users
commands.description: Query Active Directory for user account details including account properties, group memberships, login times, and password policies. Can enumerate all users or target specific accounts. Critical for identifying privileged accounts and attack targets.

variables.name: <USERNAME>
variables.description: Specific user SamAccountName to query (omit to enumerate all users)

output_analysis: samaccountname: Username
memberof: Group memberships (look for Domain Admins, Enterprise Admins)
description: Often contains passwords or useful info
pwdlastset: Password age (old passwords = potential weak passwords)
lastlogon: Active vs inactive accounts
serviceprincipalname: Service accounts (Kerberoastable)
useraccountcontrol: Account flags (disabled, password not required, etc.)
common_uses: Enumerate all domain users for targeting
Identify privileged accounts (Domain Admins)
Find service accounts for Kerberoasting
Check user descriptions for embedded passwords
Identify accounts with old passwords for password spraying
success_indicators: Returns user object(s) with populated properties
failure_indicators: No users returned when domain has users

flag_explanations.-SamAccountName: Filter to specific user account by username
flag_explanations.-SPN: Find users with Service Principal Names (Kerberoastable)
flag_explanations.-UACFilter: Filter by User Account Control flags

troubleshooting.too much output: Use -SamAccountName filter or pipe to Select-Object
troubleshooting.access denied: User may lack read permissions on user objects
troubleshooting.no results: Try Get-NetUser without parameters to enumerate all

commands.notes: OSCP Tip: Always check user 'description' field - admins often store passwords there. Use '-AdminCount 1' to quickly find privileged accounts. For Kerberoasting, look for serviceprincipalname field. Manual alternative: 'net user /domain' or 'net user <username> /domain'

commands.name: Enumerate Domain Groups
commands.description: Query Active Directory for group information and group memberships. Identifies privileged groups like Domain Admins, Enterprise Admins, and custom administrative groups. Essential for privilege escalation path mapping.

variables.name: <GROUP>
variables.description: Specific group name to query (omit to enumerate all groups)

output_analysis: samaccountname: Group name
member: Direct group members (users and nested groups)
description: Purpose of group
admincount: If 1, indicates privileged group
common_uses: Enumerate all domain groups
Identify privileged groups and their members
Find custom administrative groups
Map group hierarchy and nested memberships
Target high-value groups for attack paths
success_indicators: Member field shows DNs of members
failure_indicators: Empty member lists for known populated groups

flag_explanations.-GroupName: Filter to specific group by name

troubleshooting.access denied: User may lack read permissions on group objects

commands.notes: OSCP Focus Groups: 'Domain Admins', 'Enterprise Admins', 'Backup Operators', 'Account Operators', 'Server Operators'. These groups have elevated privileges. Use Get-NetGroupMember to see full membership recursively. Manual alternative: 'net group "<group>" /domain'

commands.name: Enumerate Domain Computers
commands.description: Query Active Directory for computer objects including workstations, servers, and domain controllers. Returns detailed information about each computer including OS version, last logon, and DNS hostname. Critical for identifying high-value targets and lateral movement candidates.
output_analysis: dnshostname: Fully qualified domain name
operatingsystem: OS version (identifies servers vs workstations)
operatingsystemversion: Build number
lastlogontimestamp: Activity indicator
serviceprincipalname: Services running on computer
useraccountcontrol: Computer account flags
common_uses: Enumerate all domain-joined computers
Identify servers for targeted attacks
Find Domain Controllers
Locate high-value targets (SQL servers, Exchange, etc.)
Build target list for lateral movement
success_indicators: Returns computer objects with multiple properties

flag_explanations.-Ping: Only return computers that respond to ping

troubleshooting.access denied: User lacks read permissions on computer objects
troubleshooting.no results: Verify domain connectivity and PowerView import

commands.notes: OSCP Strategy: Focus on servers (OperatingSystem like '*Server*') as they often have more privileges. Look for SQL servers, Exchange, domain controllers. Use -Unconstrained flag to find computers vulnerable to delegation attacks. Manual alternative: 'net view' for basic computer list.

commands.name: Find Local Admin Access
commands.description: Test current user's local administrator access on all domain computers by attempting to access admin shares (C$). Identifies systems where current user has local admin rights, critical for lateral movement and privilege escalation path discovery.
output_analysis: Returns list of computer hostnames where access succeeded
Empty result means no local admin access found
Each returned hostname is a potential lateral movement target
common_uses: Identify lateral movement targets from compromised user account
Find systems where current user is local admin
Map privilege escalation paths
Discover admin access inheritance patterns
success_indicators: Returns one or more computer hostnames

flag_explanations.-ComputerName: Test specific computer instead of all domain computers

troubleshooting.no results: Current user may not have local admin on any systems
troubleshooting.network errors: Check firewall rules and SMB connectivity
troubleshooting.very slow: Use -ComputerName to test subset of computers

commands.notes: OSCP Critical: This identifies WHERE you can move laterally. Results show systems where PSExec, WMI, or PowerShell Remoting will work. Can be slow on large domains - use -ComputerName with high-value targets list. Generates SMB traffic that may be logged. Manual alternative: Test C$ access manually with 'dir \\<computer>\C$'

commands.name: Find Network Shares
commands.description: Enumerate all accessible network shares across domain computers. Identifies potential data repositories, file servers, and misconfigurations. Critical for finding sensitive files, configuration files, and credentials stored in shares.
output_analysis: Returns list of UNC paths (\\computer\share)
Shows share name and computer hosting it
Accessible shares are those current user can read
common_uses: Find accessible file shares for data exfiltration
Locate configuration files and scripts
Discover credentials in share contents
Identify SYSVOL for Group Policy extraction
Find backup shares and sensitive data
success_indicators: Shows both default and custom shares

flag_explanations.-CheckShareAccess: Verify read access on each share (more thorough)

troubleshooting.access denied on all: User may lack domain user minimum rights

commands.notes: OSCP Priority Shares: SYSVOL (Group Policy files often contain credentials), NETLOGON (logon scripts), custom shares (user data). Look for passwords in files like Groups.xml (Group Policy Preferences), scripts, config files. Manual alternative: 'net view \\<computer>' to list shares.

commands.name: Enumerate Group Policy Objects
commands.description: Query Active Directory for Group Policy Objects (GPOs) and their configurations. GPOs often contain credentials, scheduled tasks, registry settings, and other useful information for privilege escalation and lateral movement.
output_analysis: displayname: Human-readable GPO name
gpcfilesyspath: UNC path to GPO files (\\domain\SYSVOL\...)
whenchanged: Last modification time
Properties contain XML paths for detailed settings
common_uses: Enumerate all GPOs in domain
Find GPO file paths for manual inspection
Identify custom GPOs with potential credentials
Locate scheduled tasks and startup scripts in GPOs
Discover Group Policy Preferences with passwords (Groups.xml)
success_indicators: Shows both default and custom GPOs

flag_explanations.-GPOname: Filter to specific GPO by name

troubleshooting.no results: User may lack read access to GPO container
troubleshooting.cannot access files: Navigate to gpcFileSysPath manually via UNC

commands.notes: OSCP Gold Mine: Look for Groups.xml in GPO SYSVOL paths - contains cpassword (encrypted passwords). Use gpp-decrypt to decrypt. Also check Scripts folder for logon/startup scripts that may contain credentials. Manual path: \\domain\SYSVOL\domain\Policies\{GUID}\

commands.name: Get Domain Security Identifier
commands.description: Retrieve the Security Identifier (SID) for the current or specified domain. Domain SID is required for advanced attacks like Golden Ticket and Silver Ticket attacks. Essential component for Kerberos ticket forgery.
output_analysis: Returns SID string format: S-1-5-21-xxxxxxxxxx-xxxxxxxxxx-xxxxxxxxxx
This is the base domain SID
User/group SIDs append RID (last number) to this base
common_uses: Obtain domain SID for Golden Ticket attacks
Required parameter for Mimikatz ticket creation
Identify domain in multi-domain forest
Build complete SIDs for specific users/groups

flag_explanations.-Domain: Get SID for different domain in forest

troubleshooting.no output: Verify domain membership: systeminfo | findstr Domain
troubleshooting.access denied: Should work for any domain user - check PowerView import
troubleshooting.wrong SID: Ensure querying correct domain with -Domain flag

commands.notes: OSCP Critical for Golden Tickets: Combine Domain SID + krbtgt hash + domain name to create Golden Ticket. For user SID, append RID (500 for Administrator, 512 for Domain Admins group). Manual alternative: 'whoami /user' shows current user's SID, remove last segment for domain SID. Or 'wmic useraccount get name,sid'

commands.name: Run BloodHound Collector
commands.description: Execute BloodHound data collector (SharpHound) to gather comprehensive Active Directory relationship data. Collects user sessions, group memberships, ACLs, trusts, and other relationships for graph analysis. Outputs JSON files for import into BloodHound GUI.
output_analysis: Creates ZIP file with timestamp in current directory
JSON files contain: computers, users, groups, sessions, trusts, ACLs
Progress output shows collection status per category
Completion message shows output file location
common_uses: Comprehensive AD enumeration for attack path analysis
Map privilege escalation paths to Domain Admin
Identify shortest path to high-value targets
Find Kerberoastable accounts and delegation issues
Visualize trust relationships and ACL misconfigurations

flag_explanations.-CollectionMethod All: Collect all data types (default, recommended for OSCP)
flag_explanations.-CollectionMethod Session: Only collect user sessions (faster, less noisy)
flag_explanations.-Stealth: Use stealth collection (avoid admin share enumeration)
flag_explanations.-OutputDirectory: Specify output location for ZIP file

troubleshooting.access denied: User may lack permissions for session enumeration
troubleshooting.very slow: Use -CollectionMethod Session or -Stealth for faster collection
troubleshooting.no output file: Check current directory permissions and disk space
troubleshooting.incomplete data: Some access denied errors are normal, check ZIP contents

commands.notes: OSCP Essential: BloodHound visualizes attack paths you'd have to manually map otherwise. Focus on 'Shortest Paths to Domain Admins' and 'Kerberoastable Accounts' queries. Session collection is noisy (touches every computer). Can run from Linux with bloodhound-python. Transfer ZIP to attacker machine with BloodHound GUI for analysis.
